content.body: It's a very helpful test case - saved me loads of time when implementing document.all. But it doesn't cover every named element.
It does the hard job of testing lots of attribute values.
Separately I noticed there's a RtoL control code in the source file immediately before 'Pooja Sanklecha' in the acks list. It doesn't seem to be necessary as the name always renders LtoR.

content.body: Do we already have the concept of an event loop for the "parent process" (i.e. one that operates indpendently of a specific ES global)?
jgraham: "in parallel"
Well, and you can use parallel queues if you want to sequence something ther

Right, so currently WebDriver-BiDi is using "in parallel" to defer some things, but it feels like it would be much easier if we could just reuse the task queue stuff (especially because there's a "wait for one of the following events to happen", which implementation wise is almost certainly `Promise.race` or C++ equivalent). So I was thinking of defining/handwaving a "user-agent event loop" which could then allow reusing the task scheduling.
content.formatted_body: Right, so currently WebDriver-BiDi is using "in parallel" to defer some things, but it feels like it would be much easier if we could just reuse the task queue stuff (especially because there's a "wait for one of the following events to happen", which implementation wise is almost certainly Promise.race or C++ equivalent). So I was thinking of defining/handwaving a "user-agent event loop" which could then allow reusing the task scheduling.

content.body: Obviously for Gecko in particular where we have js in the parent process, this is exactly how things actually work, although other implementations are different.
A parallel queue seems close enough

Yeah, I guess I could just use parallel queues directly, unless we care about the distinction between tasks and microtasks. It *might* be sufficiently unobservable that it doesn't matter, but in practice I"m fairly sure the implementations will actually use promises and therefore microtasks.
content.formatted_body: Yeah, I guess I could just use parallel queues directly, unless we care about the distinction between tasks and microtasks. It might be sufficiently unobservable that it doesn't matter, but in practice I"m fairly sure the implementations will actually use promises and therefore microtasks.

content.body: I would be surprised if Chromium was going to use promises (and thus V8) in the browser process...
Also, if it's cross-process you have to queue a task anyway to resolve the promise from, at which point there's no distinction
